author: Lisa Sakai Quinley
description: Extreme weather—droughts, floods, fires, hurricanes—is now the norm, driven by greenhouse gas emissions and global warming. Morocco, facing an unprecedented drought, is the focus of my thesis. What can be done now and in the future to prevent and mitigate climate disasters? While some solutions lie within Morocco, global action is crucial. I explore how to communicate climate realities and coping strategies to youth. Morocco’s case reflects a global challenge: countries must both endure the effects of climate change and work together to stop it.
title: Droughts! Floods! Fires!

author: Tak Watanabe
description: Although open data is a valuable asset across various sectors and is intended to be accessible to all, it presents technical limitations that hinder effective utilization, particularly for non-technical users. This project seeks to overcome these barriers through a combination of artificial intelligence and best practices in data aggregation and visualization. As a proof of concept, the project focuses on developing an interface for NYC Open Data’s 311 complaint dataset, aiming to demonstrate whether users can effectively derive insights from the data.
title: ASK NYC: NYC Open Data Explorer

author: Josh Strupp
description: Self-help is everywhere—books, podcasts, seminars—and whether we realize it or not, most of us are consuming it. But behind the advice to “optimize your life” lies something more insidious: a genre that often blames individuals for systemic problems, often profiting off our insecurities. This thesis examines American self-help literature—its rise, its authors, and its cultural influence—through the lens of a Goodreads dataset.
title: The Problem With Fixing Yourself

author: Hyeonjeong Kwon
description: This thesis explores the hidden risks of combining over-the-counter (OTC) medications. While these drugs are safe when used alone, their active ingredients often overlap—leading to accidental overdose when taken together. Through the project, users can explore commonly used OTC products by symptom, check for overlapping ingredients, and learn about daily dosage limits. The project helps people understand how easily they might exceed safe amounts without realizing it. By simulating real-life choices, it raises awareness about the dangers of self-medicating with multiple products and encourages more careful, informed decisions about what we put into our bodies.
title: Safe Alone, Risky Together

author: Daia Bromberg
description: Sex education in the United States has long reflected the political and moral anxieties of the adults shaping it. Codified both culturally and legally, sex ed has tried to balance fear of sexual risk with an idealized vision of sex as foundational to family and society. Queer identities, often erased or stigmatized, have been a hidden force in that tension. Today, a resurgence of censorship laws target gender and sexuality in schools, even as new research underscores the stakes for queer youth. This thesis explores the entwined histories of sex education and LGBTQIA+ exclusion—and the potential of inclusive sex education to support youth wellbeing.
title: The Missing Chapter: Queer Youth in Sex Ed

author: Monsicha Srisuantang
description: What can the storefronts of everyday places like grocery stores reveal about the city’s scenery? In a city as diverse as New York, where food cultures from around the world exist block by block, the names and signs of grocery stores offer a clues about culture, community, and identity. This project explores the design elements of these signs, both textual and visual, to reflect on how the often-overlooked language of storefronts shapes how we navigate, experience, and connect with the city’s multicultural foodscape.
title: Grocery Signery

author: Tan De Xuan
description:
Trains, Lanes, and Data Grains, a speculative exploratory urban planning engine designed for activists, policymakers, and city planners looking to shake things up. Forecasting rail connectivity development in Southeast Asia, this tool is like SimCity meets real-world infrastructure—except the stakes are higher.

By transforming biodiversity and census data into hypothetical “What-if” scenarios, it reveals indiscernible pathways through challenging terrains and natural hazards like earthquakes. Whether advocating for underserved communities or optimizing railway routes, users can explore how data-driven urban futures can reshape regional connectivity.

What if you could find the best-fit route that maximizes services to the majority of the population while avoiding seasonal hurricanes? Now, you can.
title: Trains, Lanes, and Data Grains: Mapping Southeast Asia’s Future

author: Harshita Chakravadhanula
description: This project explores female characters in literary epics across time and culture, analyzing their traits to uncover recurring archetypes. What do cultures expect of women—and how much do those expectations differ across civilizations? By studying epics as repositories of collective values, this research investigates how idealized models of femininity are constructed. It asks whether these cultural ideals become internalized, shaping the inner voice through which women learn to govern themselves. Drawing from a diverse and global selection of epic texts, the project maps the persistence and evolution of feminine archetypes across mythology, religion, nationhood, and time.
title: Cookie Cutter Women

author: Nour Al Safadi
description: The project investigates the rhetoric of Germany’s far-right party. It analyzes transcribed speeches from the party’s official YouTube channel using artificial intelligence, word frequency analysis, and natural language processing (NLP). Additionally, it introduces a predictive AI model trained on thousands of far-right speeches and the Left Party’s election program to classify how closely a speech aligns with far-right discourse. The project reveals how language fosters political division and explores the potential of AI to identify early warning signs of right-wing radicalization.
title: Language of Division

author: Katherine Chui
description: Film is a multisensory and interdisciplinary art form that can be visualized into a more accessible and immersive experience. I hope this project can be a space for exploring and enjoying the visual beauty of sound, and the intersection of music, narrative, and design.
title: Sound Stories: Visualizing Music in Film

author: Annie Lee
description: Fluid Notes is an interactive data visualization that traces how perfume has reflected and reshaped gender norms over the past century. Using data from over 25,000 perfumes and 200 vintage ads, the project explores shifting scent trends, marketing language, and gender categories — revealing that fragrance, like gender, is fluid and evolving.
title: Fluidnotes: Gender and Fragrance

author: Ani Matevosian
description: Genocide denial comments become data in this analysis of Armenian Genocide narratives circulating online. Examining over 10,000 YouTube comments alongside official Turkish government statements, this project visualizes how state narratives and propaganda shape public discourse. The interactive visualization reveals which government denial narratives are frequently echoed online, displaying both the scale and intensification of these statements. Machine learning classification identifies twelve distinct rhetorical stances, from explicit denial to minimization and justification. The comments form a searchable and downloadable archive—filterable by year, likes, and video source—transforming toxic content into a resource for studying genocide denial in digital spaces.
title: Narratives of Truth and Denial

author: Steph Wu
description: What began as a co-evolutionary relationship between humans and wolves over 130,000 years ago has given rise to specialized working dog breeds whose deeply entwined skills and sensibilities remain irreplaceable—even in our technological age. These aren't just good boys and girls—they co-evolved with us, challenging the very notion of human exceptionalism. Dogs may just be the smartest partnership we've ever made as a species.
title: Dogs with Jobs

author: Ian Yu
description: Public understanding of AI's energy cost is still at its infancy. Many users remain unaware that the AI query 'costs' anything beyond their internet connection. This project is an exploration of energy consumption of AI.
title: In the Age of AI
